title: Zune: The Failed iPod Killer - Krazy Ken’s Tech Talk
tags: Zune: The Failed iPod Killer - Krazy Ken’s Tech Talk
description: Go to to get a 30-day free trialthe first 200 people will get 20% off their annual subscription! You can support this channel on Patreon! Link below Former iPod user Krazy Ken is trying a Zune for the first time! He's going to tell you all about the product history, and he'll debunk some myths.  See more tech flops   Magic Cube episode   Patreon!    Buy my Wallpaper Mega-Pack!    Follow me on Twitter   Facebook   Shop for cool stuff on my store   Hey! I have a Discord    Support the Computer Clan on Patreon   Patrons got early access to this episode. They also got behind-the-scenes access, Discord VIP access, and their names in the credits! Pledge now to get those awesome perks, and help fund the future of the Computer Clan! Thanks for your support.   NOTE: I'd like to clarify that the original "CE" in "Windows CE" did not act as an initialism per Microsoft's design. The dev community associated various meanings with it over time.  Contact Us    Get royalty-free stock footage with Artgrid. Sign up with my link to support the channel and get 2 extra months free:   I also use Artlist for the music in my videos. I highly recommend them  Click for 2 extra months free:   Get film gear I use   On a lower budget?    Computer Clan is an Amazon Associate. Amazon links are powered by the Amazon Associates Program.  #KrazyKen #ComputerClan
transcript: - I'm so happy Microsoft got a lot of Zune product placement in "Guardians of the Galaxy." That should help boost sales. Oh, the Zune hardware was discontinued in 2011. In 2004, Microsoft launched a music store feature as part of their MSN music service. A few months before it shut down in November, 2006, reports surfaced about Microsoft working on an iPod competitor. At the time, Apple was king of media player sales, so it makes sense that someone would wanna step up and try to dethrone the fruit. Microsoft employee, J Allard, who worked on the Xbox, oversaw this new project code named Argo. On July 10th, 2006, Engadget posted a photo of what's likely a Zune prototype. Note the silver control pad as opposed to the black, and the thinner iconography on the buttons. 11 days later, Microsoft confirmed the product's name would be Zune, and they teased it with the website comingzune.com. Cesar Menendez also posted about it on Zune Insider blog. And Cesar was an employee at Microsoft, so I thought it was kind of cool that Microsoft was letting someone give the public an inside scoop on the product. One month later, an FCC filing with the name Toshiba 1089 appeared, and this apparent prototype circulated online. It looks similar to a white Zune, but the control pad is white instead of black, and there's no symbols on the buttons. Additional photos were also uncovered showing the Zune in some sort of lab testing. This unit is brown with a white control pad as opposed to a black pad on the production model. Ooh, I just love speculating about new products. It's always so much fun, but we didn't have to wait much longer, because on September 14th, 2006, Microsoft officially revealed the Zune's appearance. So let's take a look at it, and fun fact, if you look at the back of the black model, the text at the bottom says Model 1089. Coincidence? I think not! The first generation Zune, which was later named Zune 30, was manufactured by Toshiba and came in three colors. Black, white, and everybody's favorite, brown. And it sold for $250. Well, $249.99 if you like cents. The case is made of double-shot plastic, and the black color had dark blue accents around the edge, and the brown had green accents. And I really like the matte finish this plastic has. I think it feels really good in my hand, but I've noticed the plastic screen is really prone to scuffs and scratches. But don't worry, Microsoft will have a solution for that soon. The screen's bezel is silver and shiny, and that design also encloses the control pad. It's not touch-sensitive, so if you come from an iPod background, you may be tempted to scroll with a circular thumb gesture, but it's not designed to work that way. You can click the pad in four directions, and you can click and hold for faster scrolling. There's also a back button on the left and a play, pause button on the right. The three inch display is bigger than the iPod's 2.5-inch display, which I think is really nice, and it works for portrait and landscape content. However, despite the larger size, it is the same resolution as the iPod's display, 320x240. On top is the headphone jack and hold switch, and on the bottom is the connector port for charging and syncing. And on the back of the Zune is this circular thingy. I have no idea what it's for, but it's there. And it says hello from Seattle. Nice touch. Now the Zune is kind of big. It's 2.4x4.4x0.58 inches, and I think it looks like a chunky brick next to an iPod. Don't get me wrong, I still like the design of the Zune, and I abso-freaking-lutely love this black and blue color, but the size is just not appealing to me. But to each their own. And the weight is 5.6 ounces, not too different from the iPod's 4.8. I should also mention Zune came in some limited edition designs, like this "Halo" model, and this applied to future generations too. Now let's talk specs. The Zune features a 30 gigabyte hard disk drive and was advertised to hold up to 7,500 songs. It uses a free scale IMX31L processor with 64 megabytes of RAM, and the battery lasted for 12 hours of music playback or 3 1/2 hours of video playback, and it had an FM tuner built-in for radio. And it sounds good for radio. I tried it out and it sounds pretty much the same as if I would tune in on the station's website. However, my picky eye noticed that the five in decimal characters in the radio application are cropped slightly, but hey, nobody's perfect and frankly, I'm just a pixel peeper. But while we're on the topic of user interfaces, let's talk about the software. Now I've heard some folks say that Microsoft took Toshiba's software and reskinned it for the Zune, but I'm here today to debunk that little myth. Many non-Apple portable media players at the time ran Portable Media Center. Microsoft engineered the software and the Windows CE core it's based on, and they licensed it to other companies. So if you see some UI similarities between Toshiba's product and the Zune, now you know why. The Zune's graphical user interface is a program which runs on top of Microsoft Windows CE, Compact Embedded. In fact, with some computer trickery you can access CE's desktop on a Zune. I'm using version 3.3 of the software, because version three was the last major release this device supports. But if you're curious, this is what version one of the software looked like. And you don't see this too often, because pretty much every Zune is updated nowadays. The UI had smaller menu text and a different font. This whole shift of the flat look and these thin, clean fonts was a big visual change for Microsoft at the time. Internally, this was known as the Metro style before it was officially named MDL, Microsoft Design Language. Although Microsoft did say Metro a lot when they demoed stuff publicly. - Metro, Metro, Metro. - A recurring theme with this UI is two-dimensional scrolling, similar to what we saw in the Portable Media Center software. I can't fully demo these social features, because Zune Social doesn't exist anymore. But there is one social feature that still works today, and now we need to have a conversation about squirting. And depending on your sense of humor, you can interpret that a couple different ways. Let me back up and add some context here. Squirting was the common term people used when referring to the Zune's song-sharing features. This was one of the product's differentiators. You could send pictures from your Zune to your friend's Zune if you two were nearby. And you could also share a song which they could listen to for three days or three plays, whichever comes first. But I'm here to bust this myth. And I know we all love laughing at the word squirt because, apparently we're all 12 years old, and I think we have Steve Ballmer to thing for that. I really like how the bezel and play buttons are made to look like the physical Zune hardware. The Zune software lets you rip music, burn CDs, organize music, pictures and videos, and of course, you can sync all that data with your Zune. It also has a compact mode. The software also gives you access to Zune Marketplace, which replaced MSN music. You could purchase music here, TV shows and movies were added later, and you could also subscribe to Zune Pass for 14.99 a month. Zune Pass lets users download an unlimited number of songs without having to pay for them all individually, and you can play them as much as you want, as long as your membership was active. And in a November 19th, 2008 update, you could then keep 10 of those songs to permanently add to your library. And Microsoft made a compelling argument when they challenged Apple's 99 cents a song method. They said it would take about $30,000 to fill up an iPod classic solely from iTunes purchases. But ultimately, even though it kind of sounded like a good idea, looking back, it wasn't enough to save the Zune. And that brings us to the third generation Zune, which featured a big redesign in terms of the hardware and the software. Built inside of a new aluminium enclosure, designed in collaboration with Astro Studios, the same company Microsoft worked with for the Xbox 360 design. I mean, I grew up with the iPod, so I always just in my head imagined the Zune HD was the same size as the iPod in terms of the screen size. But no, it's actually much smaller. But the cool thing is it's an OLED display, which the iPod is not. That means the black pixels have no light in them making the blacks really black as opposed to a dark gray look. And this was one of the first consumer products to ship with an all LED display. So I think that's a really cool feature and a good achievement. Zune HD's UI used the Metro style we talked about earlier. It featured new animations, new iconography, and lots of tile-like elements. The iPod's video out capabilities could only go up to 480p and in some cases, 576p with Apple's Component AV Cable, according to the spec sheet. The home screen also shows a parallax effect when you tilt the Zune slightly, and it uses the accelerometer to do this. Unfortunately, there's no built-in speaker, which the iPod Touches had for a couple generations. So that's a bit of a deal breaker for me. In terms of battery, Zune HD could play music for about 33 hours and video for 8 1/2 hours, and it was available in 16 gigabyte and 32 gigabyte flash storage configurations for $220 and $290 respectively. So how, how on God's green and brown Earth did the Zune even fail? How could they not figure this out? Well, here's my breakdown. Reason one, lack of developer adoption. Many developers felt Microsoft's SDK for the Zune was incomplete. It did not offer full access to the Zune's hardware, and they were going up against the Apple Goliath. There was already a proven SDK for the iPhone and the iPod Touch with a huge app marketplace.
